An active catalyst Pd/TiO2(M) for phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone was constructed via a ball-milling process. This mechanical process avoids the thermal reduction in hydrogen atmosphere and creates oxygen vacancies on TiO2, which prevents the oxide support encapsulating active metal palladium due to the strong metal-support interaction(SMSI) but improves the catalytic performance of palladium. Under atmospheric hydrogen generated by electrolyzingwater, phenol can be hydrogenated to cyclohexanone selectively. Characterizations, control experiments and DFT calculations reveal that surface defective structures of Ti3+-Ov can stabilize Pd nanoclusters and promote the formation of electron-rich Pd. This kind of electronic metal-support interaction facilitates the dissociative adsorption of phenol, so that Pd/TiO2(M) exhibits outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity for phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Light-induced energy Oxygen vacancy Palladium Phenol Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Transition metal oxides(TMOs) can not only function as catalysts but also support for active components in heterogeneous catalysis due to their rich acid-base and redox properties [1–3]. Especially as support for active metal component, TMOs can regulate the catalytic activity and product selectivity because of the existence of classical strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [4–7]. The characteristic of classic SMSI is that the active metal is wrapped by TMOs support and the electron transfer from TMOs to metal after reduction at high temperature, which results to the regulation of catalytic performance [8–14]. In general, changing the reduction temperature or atmosphere can adjust the encapsulation extent of active metal by TMOs and built special interface between active metal and TMOs, and then alter the adsorption behaviors of reactants or intermediates [15,16]. So, it is significant to develop strategies to prepare TMOs supported catalyst possessing both excellent activity and adjustable selectivity [17–19]. TiO2, a kind of well-known semiconductor photocatalyst, is also widely applied as support of active components in heterogeneous catalysis because of its variable phase structures and redox chemistry [20–25]. Generally, the synthesis of TiO2 supported metal catalysts need thermal reduction process in hydrogen atmosphere at high temperature so that the characteristics of strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) are obvious and classical [26–28]. The defects at the interface, which results from the partial reduction of TiO2 support, result to the electronic transfer between metal and support, usually facilitate the adsorption and activation of reactants. For instance, the interfacial defects in Ni@TiO2− x catalyst promote the dissociation of the OH bonds in water and the CO oxidation activity over Au/TiO2 catalyst was also impacted by SMSI [10,9,29]. By increasing the reduction temperature, the product selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation over Ir/TiO2 can be modulated from methane to carbon monoxide but the activity decreased [30]. Plainly, the interfacial defects in TiO2 supported metal catalyst are positive for improve the catalytic performance but the encapsulation of TiO2 over metal surface hinder the interaction of reactant with metal surface [31]. That is, the positive and negative characteristics of SMSI for catalytic performance are all generated from the thermal reduction process during the synthesis of catalyst. Therefore, exploring new strategy to synthesize TiO2 supportedcatalyst just possessing the positive properties for catalytic performance instead of negative one would promote the development of this kind of catalyst. Cyclohexanone has great commercial value, and the direct hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone under mild conditions still keeps a great challenge [32,33]. In this report, mechanical ball-milling strategy was adopted to synthesize TiO2 supported palladium catalyst, which created defects on TiO2 support and reduced palladium components simultaneously. Because there was no thermal reduction process, the physical encapsulation of support on TiO2 was avoided but the interfacial defects still exist. Therefore, the achieved catalyst Pd/TiO2(M) exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity in phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone in aqueous solution in the absence of any additives. The 100% phenol conversion and 99.9% cyclohexanone selectivity were achieved at mild conditions of 90 °C with H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa. Furthermore, the phenol hydrogenation to cyclohenxanone over Pd/TiO2(M) can be achieved under the light irradiation in a photo-thermal transform tube. Characterizations proved that defects resulted from ball-milling process resulted to the electronic transfer from support to Pd, facilitating the dissociative adsorption of phenol on catalyst. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrated that the structures of Ti3+-Ov promote the dissociation of phenol and the formation of more stable adsorption configurations (-C-O-Ti-). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Tetrabutyl titanate ( >99.0%, AR ) was purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ethyl alcohol (AR) was produced from Tianjin Beichen Fangzheng Reagent Factory. Boric acid (>99.0%) was achieved from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagents Factory. Palladium acetylacetonate and commercial nano TiO2 ( P25 ) were obtained from Shanghai MACKLIN reagent. All chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Preparation of TiO2 In a typical procedure, boric acid (5 g), ethanol absolute (10 mL) and tetrabutyl titanate (10 mL) were added to a 50 mL beaker in sequence. The mixture was stirred with a glass rod until it became into a dry powder. Then it was dried at 80 °C in oven for 6 h. Then, the powder was boiled in deionized water (600 mL) for 2 h, and then thermally filtered to remove boric acid or boron oxide in the sample. Finally, the product was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. The final product was named TiO2. 2.3 Preparation of Pd/TiO2(x) Typically, TiO2 (0.5 g) and Pd(acac)2 (0.0072 g, containing 0.0025 g Pd) were sequentially weighed into a stainless steel pot containing ten stainless steel balls with 8 mm diameter. In another pot, commercial P25 (0.5 g) was weighed instead of TiO2. Then the two pots were fixed on a planetary ball mill and milled at a rate of 300 r/min for 3 h. The achieved samples containing 0.5 wt% palladium were named Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/P25(M). As a control sample, the sample achieved by fully ground in an agate mortar was named Pd/TiO2(G). 2.4 Characterizations The morphology of all samples is characterized by transmission electronic microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20 STWIN). TEM samples were prepared by picking samples in dilute ethanol suspensions using copper grids. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was performed on a JEM-ARM200F microscope. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of all samples are achieved on a diffractometer (Bruker D8 ADVANCE) with Cu kα (λ= 1.5418 Å). Diffraction patterns were obtained within the 2θ range of 20°to 80° at a scan rate of 4° min1 under the conditions of 40 kV and 40 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) data are recorded on an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo ESCALAB 250XI). Nitrogen adsorption desorption experiments are conducted on an automatic specific surface and porosity analyzer (JW-BK100C). The dispersion of palladium in samples was determined by H2 pulse titration on a chemisorption instrument (VDsorb-91i). For the H2 chemisorption experiment, the sample was pre-treated in air flow at 120 °C for 60 min, followed by purging with Ar for 30 min. After cooling down to 50 °C, H2 was injected into the reactor repeatedly until saturated adsorption is achieved. The dispersion of Pd NPs was determined by assuming the or H/Pd adsorption stoichiometry to be 1:1 and using the stoichiometry shown in Eq. (1). (1) PdO + 3 / 2 H 2 = PdH + H 2 O Besides, H2 temperature-programmed desorption experiment was conducted to compare the capacity of different sample to store active hydrogen on chemisorption instrument (VDsorb-91i) and the desoprtion of H2 was monitored by an online mass spectrometer (HIDEN, HPR-40). The sample was loaded in an U-type quartz tube and flushed with hydrogen of 30 mL‧min−1. Then, the sample was heated to 90 °C and maintained at this temperature for 30 min. After the furnace was cooled down to room temperature, the nitrogen gas was switched into the system to remove the hydrogen and physical adsorbed hydrogen on sample. After 90 min, the sample was heated to 600 °C with a ramp of 10 °C min−1 in nitrogen flow of 30 mL‧min−1. To investigate the different adsorption mode of phenol, Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analyses were conducted on a NICOLET iS10 FTIR spectrometer with HARRICK diffuse reflection accessory. The background spectrum of the sample was collected under N2 flow and 353 °C. To carry the vapor of the phenol, N2 gas flowed (30 mL‧min−1) through a saturator containing phenol. After adsorbing phenol for 30 min, switch to purge the surface with pure N2 for 20 min to collect the final spectrum at 353 K. 2.5 Catalytic performance Typically, phenol aqueous solution (3 mL, containing 1 mmol phenol) and catalyst (0.1067 g) were introduced into a 20 mL stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and purged with hydrogen (0.1 MPa) ten times to remove air, and connected to hydrogen pipe at H2 pressure (0.1 MPa). Then the autoclave was placed on a metal mold which was pre-heated and maintained at 90 °C under stirring at 700 rpm. After reaction, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature quickly. Dodecane (0.05 g) was weighted into the mixture as internal standard, and organic substances was extracted by ethyl acetate. Then the obtained chemical mixture was analyzed by gas chromatography after filtration. For the photothermal catalytic phenol hydrogenation, the same amount of catalyst and phenol solution as described above were charged into a pressure-resistant glass vessel [34].The glass vessel was then sealed and connected via a pipeline to a hydrogen generator. The air in the vessel was purged out with hydrogen of 0.1 MPa before the light irradiation with 0.15 sun radiation.The reaction was maintained for 2 h, and the temperature of the reaction solution was measured by a thermocouple. The actual temperature can be controlled by adjusting the light radiation, which ensured the temperature required for phenol hydrogenation reaction. 2.6 Recycling experiment After each experiment, the catalyst was filtered and washed with ethyl acetate. Then, the catalyst was dried in oven at 80 °C, which was then utilized for the next turn of recycle experiment under identical conditions. 2.7 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations DFT calculations were performed by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP 5.4). According to the experimental data, anatase TiO2 was chosen as the research object. By cleaving the bulk TiO2 in (101) direction, TiO2(101) was obtained and it contained eight Ti atomic layers and sixteen O atomic layers. The Pd(111) was simplified to a plane composed of 3 Pd atoms. The oxygen defective surfaces TiO2-x(101) and Pd3/TiO2-x(101) are built by removing two lattice oxygen atoms from corresponding surfaces. For all the interface models, tow uppermost layers can fully relax during the optimization. A vacuum space of 15 Å ensures no spurious interaction between the periodically repeated slabs or adsorbates in the direction normal to the slab. A 2 × 2 × 1 MonkhorstPack K point mesh and a 400 eV cutoff energy for the plane-wave basis were employed for geometry optimizations. The convergence criterion for the total energy self-consistent iterations was 10−4 eV. The adsorption energy (Eads) are calculated by the following equations: Eads = Etotal- Esurface- Eadsorbate, where Etotal was the calculated total energy of the adsorption system, Esurface was the energy of the clean catalyst, and Eadsorbate was the energy of the gas-phase molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterizations TiO2 was synthesized by hydrolyzing tetrabutyl titanate in ethanol absolute in the assistance of boric acid [35]. Then, Pd/TiO2(M) was achieved by ball milling the mixture of acetylacetone palladium and TiO2. If P25 was used as support instead of TiO2, the achieved sample was named Pd/P25(M). As control sample, Pd/TiO2(G) was achieved by manual grinding the mixture in agate mortar. Firstly, the phase structure of the three samples was firstly investigated by XRD analysis (Fig. 1 a). Due to the low palladium content of 0.5 wt% and high dispersion, no characteristic diffraction of palladium species was observed in XRD patterns. The diffraction peaks locating at 25.28°, 37.80°, 48.05°, 53.90°, 55.06°, 62.69°, 68.8°, 70.31° and 75.03° correspond to (101), (004), (200), (105), (211), (213), (116), (220) and (215) crystallographic plane of anatase [22]. It can be observed that the diffraction peaks of sample Pd/P25(G) were sharper than Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/TiO2(G), suggesting the higher crystallinity of P25 than TiO2. The intensity and width of these diffraction peaks in Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/TiO2(G) are same, indicating that the ball milling process do not change the phase structure of TiO2. Raman characterization is usually applied to analyze the defects and grain size of titanium oxide according to the Raman shift titanium oxide. As shown in Fig. 1b, the higher intensity of Raman shift at 144 cm−1 for Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/TiO2(G) than Pd/P25(M) indicated that the grain size of TiO2 was smaller than P25. The blue shift of Eg(144 cm−1) mode of Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/TiO2(G) suggested that the concentration of oxygen vacancies (defects) in TiO2 was higher than in P25 and ball milling process can increase this kind of defect in TiO2 [5]. The higher concentration of defect in Pd/TiO2(M) may enhance its catalytic activity in catalytic hydrogenation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is selected to further identify surface electronic environment of elements in the three samples. The XPS Ti2p spectra of the three samples show a pair of peaks at 458.8 eV and 464.5 eV, corresponding to Ti2p3∕2 and Ti2p1∕2 of Ti4+(Fig. 2 a) [30,36,37,38]. However, a new pair of peaks belonging to Ti3+ components can be deconvolved in the spectra of Pd/TiO2(G) and Pd/TiO2(M) and the concentration of Ti3+ species in Pd/TiO2(M) (8.6At%) is higher than in Pd/TiO2(G) ( 5.1At% ) ( Table S1 ). Furthermore, the XPS O1s spectra can be deconvolved into four components: lattice oxygen species at 530 eV, C = O at 531.1 eV, chemisorbed oxygen and hydroxyl species (Ov) at 531.9–532.3 eV and CO at 533.6 eV (Fig. 2b) [39,40]. Commonly, the chemisorbed oxygen including O2 2−and O − species can be stored at surface oxygen vacancies(Ov). So, the ratio of this deconvolved peak is then proportional to the Ov concentration in sample. It can be clearly observed that the proportion of Ov species increased gradually in the order of Pd/P25(M) < Pd/TiO2(G) < Pd/TiO2(M), suggesting that the synthesized TiO2 has higher concentration of oxygen vacancy than p25 and the high-energy mechanical billing process can increase this kind of defects. Therefore, the proportion of Ti3+ species in sample Pd/TiO2(M) is higher than Pd/P25(M) and Pd/TiO2(G). In XPS Pd3d spectra of Pd/P25(M) (Fig. 2c), the peaks situating around 335.3 eV and 340.6 eV in all sample belong 3d5∕2 and 3d3∕2 of Pd0, and the peaks locating around 337.1 eV and 342.5 eV correspond to 3d5∕2 and 3d3∕2 of Pd2+components [41–43]. The Pd3d spectra of Pd/P25(M) show a slight positive shift about 0.2 eV relative to standard spectrum of Pd0, suggesting the absence of defects in the P25 even after ball-milling process. In contrast, the 3d5∕2 peak of Pd0 in Pd/TiO2(M) show a big negative shift of about 0.6 eV, which indicates the enrichment of some negative charges on metallic palladium components. Combined with the results of XPS analyses, we consider that this negative shift is due to the increase of Ov concentration. The above results demonstrate the existence of electronic metal-support interactions in Pd/TiO2(M) and the high-energy ball milling process can reduce palladium acetylacetonate partially. In the HRTEM image of Pd/TiO2(M)(Fig. 3 a,b), the crystal lattice of TiO2 can be observed clearly [44]. However, it is difficult to discriminate palladium nanocluster due to its low content and high dispersion. The HAADF-STEM image of Pd/TiO2(M) shows that the palladium nanoclusters with bright contrast are anchored on TiO2 nanoparticle (Fig. 3b). The sample Pd/TiO2(G) has similar HRTEM image with Pd/TiO2(M) (Fig. 3c), indicating the high dispersion of palladium component. In contrast, Pd nanoparticles ( 3 nm ) with dark contrast can be observed in the HRTEM image of Pd/P25(M) (Fig. 3d). Correspondingly, the dispersion of palladium in the three samples were measured by H2 adsorption and followed the order of Pd/TiO2(M) (40.1%) > Pd/TiO2(G) (38.1%) > Pd/P25(M) (21.6%) (Table S2). This result illustrates that the synthesized TiO2 itself has a property of well dispersing palladium species than P25, and the ball-milling process can further increase the dispersion of palladium. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of Pd/TiO2(G) and Pd/TiO2(M) exhibit a type IV isotherm with an H2-type hysteresis loop (Fig. 4 ), reflecting the presence of mesoporous structures [45]. Also, the BET surface area of samples gradually increase from 95 (Pd/P25(M)) to 318 m2/g (Pd/TiO2(M)). The higher surface area of sample Pd/TiO2 (M) may be an important factor making a high dispersion of palladium. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalysts The catalytic performance of Pd/TiO2(M), Pd/TiO2(G) and Pd/P25(M) in phenol hydrogenation was evaluated at 90 °C under 0.1 MPa hydrogen atmosphere. As show in Fig. 5 a, the consumption rate of phenol was almost equal to the generation rate of cyclohexanone in the first two hours over catalyst Pd/TiO2(M), and no cyclohexanol was detected in this stage. The conversion of phenol reached to 100% and the selectivity to cyclohenxanone remained at 99.9% at the reaction time of 2 h. After that, cyclohexanone was hydrogenated to cyclohexanol at a low reaction rate. However, even if the reaction time was extended to 3 h, the selectivity to cyclohexanone still remaine above 90%. In contrast, the hydrogenation rates of phenol over Pd/TiO2(G) and Pd/P25(M) were slower than over Pd/TiO2(M). With Pd/TiO2(G) as catalyst(Fig. 5b), it almost needed 2.5 h to achieve the 100% conversion of phenol, then cyclohexanone was can be hydrogenated to cyclohexanol with a higher rate than over Pd/TiO2(M) when the reaction time was prolonged. Moreover, Pd/P25(M) showed the slowest reaction rate for phenol hydrogenation but the highest cyclohexanone hydrogenation rate (Fig. 5c).The apparent activation energy of phenol hydrogenation over Pd/TiO2(M) (20.4 kJ /mol) was smaller than over Pd/TiO2(G) (24.4 kJ /mol) and Pd/P25(M) (43.3 kJ /mol) (Fig. 5d). Therefore, we concluded that the higher dispersion and smaller size of palladium clusters of Pd/TiO2(M) contributed to the best catalytic performance in phenol hydrogenation, and the electronic interaction between palladium nanoclusters and TiO2(M) resulted from oxygen vacancy on support may be the essential factor. The rate constant of phenol hydrogenation( 0.01348 min−1 ) over sample Pd/TiO2(M) was more than ten times than that of cyclohexanone hydrogenation( 0.00119 min−1 ), further demonstrating the high selectivity to cyclohexanone of Pd/TiO2(M) ( Fig. 5e ). In comparison with other reported system for phenol hydrogenation ( Table S3 ), Pd/TiO2(M) exhibited a higher catalytic activity due to the smaller dosage of palladium and lower hydrogen pressure. In addition, Pd/TiO2(M) still has a high conversion rate and selectivity to cyclohexanone even after 4 times cycles, which indicates that the catalyst has excellent stability ( Fig. 5f ). In order to further explore the application range of Pd/TiO2 (M), thehydrogenation of phenolic compounds containing different substituent groups under the optimal reaction conditions. The results of these hydrogenation reactions are presented in Table 1 . 3.3 Light-irradiation thermal catalytic phenol hydrogenation To further enhance the green and sustainable properties of this catalytic system for phenol hydrogenation, a vacuum covered tube, which can absorb light irradiation and convert the solar energy to thermal energy in it, was adopted to promote the phenol hydrogenation over Pd/TiO2(M). As shown in Fig. 6 a, 92% phenol conversion and 100% cyclohexanone selectivity were achieved in 1.5 h. With the extension of reaction time, 100% phenol conversion rate and 97% cyclohexanone selectivity were achieved in 1.7 h. This performance is better than our previous report in which cellulose-supported palladium catalyst (Cel-1Pd) can also achieve phenol hydrogenation in the photo-thermal transformtube under light irradiation [34]. As a comparison, we performed the phenol hydrogenation reaction under the direct irradiation of 0.15 standard sunlight intensity, and only 8% phenol conversion was achieved in 1.5 h (Fig. 6b). This result suggests that this catalytic system for phenol hydrogenation can be accelerated by solar irradiation with the help of the photo-thermal transformation tube. In comparison with other photocatalytic system [46,47], the key factors such as absorption wavelength and quantum efficiency contributing to photocatalytic performance of catalyst are not important. The reaction temperature for the phenol hydrogenation should be higher than 80 °C, which is essential to accelerate the reaction. So, the direct irradiation cannot promote the reaction effectively. 3.4 DFT calculations DFT calculations were performed to understand whether and how the oxygen vacancies work to alter the adsorption behaviors of the phenol molecule. Firstly, we calculated the adsorption configuration of Pd cluster on the TiO2(101) surface (Fig. S1). The adsorption energies of Pd cluster on the surface without or with oxygen vacancies are −2.14 and −4.68 eV, respectively. This result confirms that surface oxygen vacancies are favorable for the adsorption of Pd, which leads to smaller Pd nanoclusters. Then, the configurations of phenol adsorbed on Pd/TiO2(101) and Pd/TiO2− x containing oxygen vacancies were further investigated. As shown in Fig. 7 a,b, the adsorption energy of phenol (Eads-phenol) on the on the Ti3+-Ov-containing catalytic systems (−1.00 eV) was much lower than that Pd/TiO2(101)surface (−0.59 eV). The bond length of phenolic hydroxyl on Pd/TiO2-x was longer than on Pd/TiO2 (101), suggesting that oxygen vacancies may facilitate the dissociation of OH bond. Indeed, the dissociative adsorption energy of phenol (Edis-phenol ) on Pd/TiO2-x ( −2.85 eV ) was lower than on Pd/TiO2(−0.97 eV) (Fig. 7c,d), which mean more stable adsorption configurations. Furthermore, due to the presence of oxygen vacancies, the Ti3+-Ov sites on the surface would promote the formation of electron-rich Pd0, which makes hydrogen molecules easier to be activated. These activated H atoms are capable of hydrogenating phenoxy to cyclohexanone rapidly. In summary, such formed electron-rich Pd atoms and the site of Ti3+-Ov are constructive to the adsorption and hydrogenation of phenol. To further demonstrate the DFT results about phenol on catalyst, H2-TPD and the DRIFT spectra of phenol adsorption on different catalysts were carried out (Fig. 8 ). The peaks below 320 °C in the H2-TPD profiles belong to the decomposition and the ones around 420 °C correspond to the desorption of the split-over hydrogen species on support [48]. As shown in Fig. 8a and Table S2, the amount of both kinds of hydrogen adsorbed on Pd/TiO2(M)(615.1 umol/g) is higher than the ones on Pd/TiO2(G) (373.1 umol/g) and Pd/P25(M) (21.6 umol/g). However, the theoretical adsorption on palladium atoms in catalyst should be only 47.0 umol/g if one hydrogen atom is adsorbed on per palladium atom. So, we concluded that the more oxygen vacancies in Pd/TiO2(M) enhance the adsorption capacity of active hydrogen so that Pd/TiO2(M) exhibited high catalytic activity for the phenol hydrogenation. Furthermore, the DRIFT spectra of phenol adsorption on different catalyst are shown in Fig. 8b. The bands at 1588 and 1490 cm−1 are attributed to the vibration modes C=C of ring in phenol molecule, and the vibration adsorption of phenolic hydroxyl group contribute to the band at about 1284 cm−1 [49]. In comparison, the intensity of adsorption signal of phenol on Pd/TiO2(M) is larger than that on Pd/TiO2(G) and Pd/P25(M). It is worth noting that the vibration bands of phenol on the Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/TiO2(G) containing defects exhibited different adsorption behaviors. The bands at 1275 cm−1 on the sample Pd/TiO2(M) and Pd/TiO2(G) containing defects suggest the partially dissociative adsorption of phenol [50], which is in accordance with the results of DFT calculations. In contrast, more phenolic hydroxyl group species (1290 cm−1) were observed on the surface of the Pd/P25(M). Besides, the red shift of phenol adsorbed species on the Pd/TiO2(M) catalyst surface may be due to charge transfer from TiO2 to Pd can negatively charge metal clusters on the surface, which is consistent with the XPS analyses. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully prepared highly dispersed palladium nanoparticles over the defect-rich TiO2 support using a simple mechanical ball milling. Pd/TiO2(M) catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone at mild conditions of 90 °C and 0.1 MPa hydrogen pressure. Especially, 92% phenol conversion and 100% cyclohexanone selectivity were achieved at 0.15 standard sunlight intensity and 1.5 h with the assistance of photo-thermal transformation tube. Combining catalytic experiments, characterizations and DFT calculations, it was revealed that the electronic interaction between metal and TiO2 containing oxygen vacancies can promote the formation of electron-rich Pd0 and benefit the anchoring of Pd nanoclusters. Furthermore, the site of Ti3+−Ov promote the dissociation of phenol and the formation of more stable adsorption configurations of intermediate species (-C-O-Ti-). This finding provides a simple and effective strategy for designing efficient and stable catalysts with low metal loading, and deliver a green and sustainable path for phenol hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: An active catalyst Pd/TiO2(M) for phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone was constructed via a ball-milling process. This mechanical process avoids the thermal reduction in hydrogen atmosphere and creates oxygen vacancies on TiO2, which prevents the oxide support encapsulating active metal palladium due to the strong metal-support interaction(SMSI) but improves the catalytic performance of palladium. Under atmospheric hydrogen generated by electrolyzingwater, phenol can be hydrogenated to cyclohexanone selectively. Characterizations, control experiments and DFT calculations reveal that surface defective structures of Ti3+-Ov can stabilize Pd nanoclusters and promote the formation of electron-rich Pd. This kind of electronic metal-support interaction facilitates the dissociative adsorption of phenol, so that Pd/TiO2(M) exhibits outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity for phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of defects-rich TiO2-supported Pd catalyst for phenol hydrogenation with ball-milling process
